steps.title: Omniromantic refers to a romantic attraction to all genders.
steps.content: Omniromantic refers to a romantic attraction to all genders. If someone identifies as omniromantic, they’re romantically attracted to every gender but may prefer one over another. They might find specific traits attractive in certain genders or find every gender equally attractive—it’s all individual. Many omniromantics date people who use non-binary pronouns. “Omni-” is from the Latin word omnis , which means “all” or “everything.” Unfortunately, the history of this romantic orientation isn’t as well known. It’s unknown when the term “omniromantic” was first used or when it became a classification within the LGBTQ+ community.

steps.title: You may be omniromantic if you’re attracted to all genders.
steps.content: You may be omniromantic if you’re attracted to all genders. For some, knowing your romantic or sexual orientation can be eye-opening. So, how do you know if you’re an omniromantic? Ask yourself these questions and answer them honestly to learn more about your identity. If you answer “yes” to them, you’re likely omniromantic. Am I attracted to people of all genders? Does gender or sex play a factor in my attraction to others? [1] X Research source Am I more attracted to people with multiple genders? It might help to take a closer look at your personal gender preferences before entering a relationship. You might come to a conclusion like "I want to date women because..." or "I like to date men over women because..."

steps.title: Omnisexual
steps.content: Omnisexual Omnisexual refers to a sexual attraction to multiple genders. Someone who is omnisexual is sexually attracted to all genders, whereas someone who is omniromantic is romantically attracted to all genders. [2] X Research source Believe it or not, romantic and sexual attraction aren’t the same thing. While someone may be omniromantic, they might not be omnisexual. [3] X Research source In other words, if someone’s omnisexual, they enjoy being physically intimate with all genders. If someone’s omniromantic, they get crushes and romantic feelings for all genders.

steps.title: Asexual omniromantic
steps.content: Asexual omniromantic This term refers to someone who is romantically attracted to all genders but isn’t sexually attracted to anyone.

steps.title: Biromantic
steps.content: Biromantic If someone is biromantic, they're romantically attracted to two or more genders. Bisexuality is this romantic orientation’s counterpart. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Demisexual omniromantic
steps.content: Demisexual omniromantic Someone who is romantically attracted to anyone regardless of gender but only has a sexual attraction to someone after forming a strong emotional bond is referred to as a demisexual omniromantic. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Panromantic
steps.content: Panromantic If someone is panromantic, they're romantically attracted to people of all genders and sexual orientations. [6] X Research source While panromantics and omniromantics are both attracted to all genders; omniromantics can have strong preferences for who they’re attracted to.

steps.title: Polyromantic
steps.content: Polyromantic This term refers to someone who is romantically attracted to multiple genders but not all of them. [7] X Research source

steps.title: The omniromantic flag is pink, purple, and blue.
steps.content: The omniromantic flag is pink, purple, and blue. This romantic orientation’s flag includes 5 equal horizontal stripes with an outline of a heart in the middle. From top to bottom, the stripes are light pink, dark pink, dark purple, light purple, and light blue. There are many versions of the omniromantic and omnisexual flags; however, this is the most common. The flag's colors represent the multiple genders an omniromantic is attracted to (from people in and out of the binary and gender spectrum).

steps.title: The best way to support an omniromantic is to be respectful.
steps.content: The best way to support an omniromantic is to be respectful. Kindness goes a long way. If you have a friend, family member, or colleague who identifies as an omniromantic, be an ally by respecting their choice to love whoever they like. Not everyone is the same, and that’s okay! Know that everyone’s romantic and/or sexual preferences are unique. [8] X Trustworthy Source LGBTQIA Resource Center The LGBTQIA Resource Center of the University of California, Davis. Go to source On top of this, avoid making assumptions about someone’s romantic or sexual orientation. At the end of the day, we’re all human.
